Name: Tradejack
Description:
A fast-paced card game about the consequences of the choices we make. Your goal is to run a successful and sustainable business, sourcing palm oil products for supermarkets. Palm oil can be found in 50% of packaged goods on your supermarket’s shelves, often with devastating consequences for the environment. Build the reputation of your brand by bringing more responsible products to market, reinvesting your profits wisely, and winning awards to edge out the competition and emerge victorious.

On your turn, you'll have to outbid your competitors to control the sources of palm oil most valuable to your market. Match Source Cards to Product Cards in order to sell - hopefully for a profit. Each round plays differently, with various regulations and consumer trends to account for, and different awards up for grabs. At the end of the game, the player with the best Reputation from awards and profit will be declared the winner.

What if we really cared how our products are sourced? Would supermarkets, with all the power they have, start to behave differently? From farmer to consumer, Tradejack provides an overview of the supply chains that bring products into our homes.

—description from the publisher

Name: Soccer Farkel
Description: This is a newer, Soccer Themed, version of the classic Farkel (or Farkle). Game mechanics are similar to original but special bonuses that follow the Soccer theme. Basically a Dice-Rolling Math Game with Football Features and Chrome. Good stocking stuffer gift for a soccer fan. G-O-A-L!!!

Name: Until the Bitter End
Description:
A print and play WW2 wargame for two players and solitaire that takes around half an hour to setup and play.

The game sets a small squad of British Airborne against their German enemies in a series of small skirmish scenarios. The game's counters (or chits) each represent an actual soldier with the gameplay being in the thick of man-to-man combat.

The game can be played 2-player with one player playing as the British Airborne and the other player playing as the Germans. The game can also be played Solitaire with the player playing as the British Airborne against the German AI. For gamers familiar with Solitaire wargames this game uses a random chit-pull mechanic (as detailed in the video).

The game is played in a number of Turns. In each Turn the player(s) randomly picks a Pull Chit from the mug and activate their Infantry. The Game Turn ends when all the Pull Chits have been removed from the cup.

The player whose Pull Chit this force belongs to can now Activate one Infantry Counter. In activating the Infantry Counter the player can choose from several Actions such as Firing against the enemy, moving, charging into close combat, applying first aid, or attempting to fix a jammed weapon.

Combat is simple and effective without needing buckets of dice. Players must establish range, line of sight and any modifiers. 
Close combat is particularly brutal and decisive with the playing be able to declare charges into combat.
Snap Fire is a defensive fire mechanic where your Infantry Counters can fire on moving enemy counters.

Finally, the game features a unique mechanic in the shape of Bravery Points. These can be used to force the enemy to re-roll a dice against one of your Infantry Counters, but should you loose you will have less Bravery Points for the rest of the game.

Solitaire Game
The Solitaire takes the key gameplay from the two player game such as Combat Resolution and Movement etc and layers in specific Solitaire rules, AI for the opposing German forces and special Solitaire scenarios.

The Solitaire game features a full and simple AI to handle the opposing force, that will take you step-by-step to which order the enemy counters should be activated and their actions.

Name: Smuggles n' Snuggles
Description:
Smuggles n' Snuggles is a 2 player strategy card game where players compete as crime families of bootleggin' bears in the 1920s! borrowing from classic playing card games, each card needs only one number. However, with a few simple rules, all your cards take on new roles as they move around the table - sometimes smuggling their fuzzy family members into rival territory or snuggling the competition with big ole bear hugs. Combining these tactics and letting each bear do what they do best will be the keys to victory.

—description from the designer

Name: Hail Caesar: Shield Wall
Description:
A notoriously unstable and rebellious member of the Roman Empire, Britannia was thrown into bloody conflict as the Western Roman Empire began to crumble. Axe, spear and sword became the dominant currency for those vying for control of the kingdoms.

Shield Wall is a supplement for Hail Caesar which introduces the main battles, armies and personalities of the Dark Ages in the British Isles from around 400AD up to 1000AD.

In addition to the traditional Hail Caesar massed battles the supplement introduces rules for smaller scale engagements between warbands as reflects much of this period. Shield Wall also contains campaign rules and several linked scenarios ­– from Badon Hill to Brunaburh.

The army lists are included for Limitanei, early and late Saxons, Romano-British, Welsh-Cymru, Irish, Picts, Gaels, Vikings and Irish-Norse.

—description from the publisher

Name: Critical Mass: 15mm Sci Fi Company Level Battle System
Description:
The Critical Mass 15mm rule system is a fast play alternative action company level game. Infantry are based in multiples and form platoons, vehicles are based individually and grouped to form units. Each game round players must manage their units activations with play continually moving back and forth as each unit is activated meaning games a tense and involved. As you would expect from a sci-fi game Walkers, Drop Troops, Grav Tanks, and much more are a plenty, coupled with lots destruction and mission defined battlefield objectives.

—description from publisher

Name: Treasure Hogs
Description:
Deep in the heart of the desert, from the far corners of the earth, Archeologists from around the world search for treasure from centuries past...

Treasure hogs is a competitive, fast pace card game where players take on the role of an Archeologist and compete to become the ultimate Treasure Hog. Watch out! Every turn is filled with surprises! Thieves lurk in the shadows and your riches could be stolen at any moment!

In Treasure Hogs, players use resources from their hand each having value ranging from one to three, hogging as many treasures as possible on their turn. The more value used to gain the available treasure, the less chance another player will be able to steal your riches!

Out of turn, you may use one or more Thief cards to steal the active player’s treasure.  Once the value has been declared, if your thieves’ combined value is equal or more, shout “OINK!” to steal all the treasure the opposing player was attempting to gain.

When all the treasures are claimed, the player with the most treasure points wins and becomes the Ultimate Treasure Hog!

Treasure Hogs is for 2-5 players, easy to learn and can be played in under 30 minutes. Designed for ages 10 & up.

Name: Aromat
Description:
Aromat is an abstract strategy game that uses a mobile app for score calculation and score keeping. The heart of the game is the hexagonal game tile, consisting of shapes, numbers, dots and a player Emblem Sign.

You can play Aromat by placing the Game Tiles next to each other. Each special calculation created by the two adjacent sides of the Tiles following the gameplay rules either adds or subtracts a certain amount of points to your Game Score. The mobile app does the score calculation and score keeping for you.

Aromat can be played using Play Field Elements by constructing these elements before the game starts. It can also be played without, which requires more thinking because of the many possibilities present in any given moment during gameplay. Therefore it is recommended to use the Play Field Elements until a player becomes strategically aware of the many possibilities the game has to offer.

Research in neuroscience, human behavior and interaction and music didactics has been conducted in order to construct the methods and mechanisms behind Aromat. It contains beneficial aspects in terms of brain training and musicality training, which are achieved in a fun and engaging way.

Aromat is a collectible game that starts out with the "Basic Set" and expands through a system of "Extension Sets"'

—description from the publisher

Name: Simulation Theory
Description:
What if everyone you know, loved, and remembered are just complex simulations in a computer-generated universe? What if you began to see through the shroud that separates what you think is your life from what is real? What if you wake up from this simulation, only to wonder if you are in another?

With multiple play modes for competitive, solo, or even cooperative play, what happens next is completely up to you. You can play the game in the standard Classic mode, the more complex Challenge mode, or the stretch goal based Adventure mode, which will allow you to match wits against a litany of enemies.

Compete with your friends in a race to ascend to the ultimate reality! Choose cooperative play to collaborate with your rivals or plot each others’ downfall. Or go solo and practice your skills at breaking out of the simulation.

The base game will include 3 realities, each with 5 unique characters. A 6th character per reality will be available as a stretch goal. Each of these characters has their own strengths and weakness plus a unique backstory which has a real impact in the Adventure mode.

—description from the publisher

Name: Patrol: A Coloring Card Game
Description:
GAME SYSTEM

    
    
         This entry is to allow for discussion/rating of the game system as a whole. It is not for a specific product or release. Versions will appear on the individual item pages.

    



The Patrol: A Coloring Card Game features soldier cards with unique artwork and abilities. 2 players split 5 Soldier cards into patrols to utilize strategy and a hide/reveal system to destroy their enemies. At the end of the battle, soldier cards that are still alive and face up receive a level(+1/+1). The player gains 1 point for each level gained this way. First player to 20 points wins the war. 
Players are also able to enhance each card with 12 different colors/abilities. Each color/abilities provides a unique play style and allows for the creation of unique decks for each player. Players draft their deck by coloring in their cards to pull from 1080 different combinations of cards.—description from the designer

Name: Niimura Station
Description:
Niimura Station is a solitaire game in which you run a small train station in Japan. To win the game you will need to satisfy the needs of the Travelers who are waiting at your station and not run out of money before all the trains have come and gone for the day.

The game is very loosely based on the real life Niimura station which is part of the KamikÅchi Line run by Alpico KÅtsÅ« Co., Ltd. in the Nagano Prefecture of Japan.
Families: Contests: Nathan Hansen 52 Game Design Challenge

Name: Rejtély a babaházban
Description:
The tiny diamond ring of Lisette Black, the beautiful doll has disappeared! The inhabitants of the magnificent dollhouse set out to  investigate who, where, when and why hid the jewel.

Regardless of the number of players, eight dolls are used in this deduction game. In each turn, 3 action points are at the players’ disposal for diceless movement and/or other actions. They use a handful of cards to make assumptions and narrow down the possibilities through the reaction of others. The player who successfully identifies the perpetrator and all the circumstances of the theft wins the game.

This investigation/deduction game can be played by 3-8 players. Despite the dollhouse environment, the game is recommended from at least 8 years of age, but it is more suitable for bigger kids, and is challenging for adults as well.

The graphics of the game board and the cards are very special. They meticulously depict a world of 18-19th century dolls and dollhouses, the originals of which are parts of the amazing collection of the Hetedhét Toy Museum of Székesfehérvár, Hungary. The very first piece of the game was made for the Museum itself.

—description from the publisher (translated)

EltÅ±nt a szépséges Lisette Black baba apró gyémántgyÅ±rÅ±je! A pazar babaház lakói összefognak, hogy kinyomozzák, ki és hová, mikor, hogyan rejthette a páratlan ékszert.

A játékosok ebben a dobókocka nélküli dedukciós játékban nyolc babát irányítanak. Három akciópont áll rendelkezésükre, amelyet a helyiségek közötti mozgásra és/vagy egyéb akciókra használhatnak fel.  Kártyák segítségével ellenÅ‘rizhetik a feltételezéseiket és szÅ±kíthetik a kört.  A játékot az nyeri, aki hiánytalanul megnevezi a tettest és az összes körülményt.

A Rejtély a bababházban 3-8 játékos által játszható dedukciós, nyomozós játék, ami 8 éves kortól ajánlott. Annak ellenére, hogy színterét egy babaház adja, ez a játék kifejezetten a nagyobb korosztálynak szól, sÅ‘t a felnÅ‘tteknek is izgalmas, kihívásokkal teli játékélményt nyújt.

A különleges játéktáblán és kártyákon ábrázolt, 18-19. századi babaszoba-enteriÅ‘rök eredetije a székesfehérvári Hetedhét Játékmúzeum gyÅ±jteményének egyes darabjait ábrázolja; a játék legelsÅ‘ példánya is eredetileg a múzeum számára készült.

—description from the publisher (Hungarian)

Name: Kingdom of Fools
Description:
This game uses the same cards as Marionette Kingdom but is only for 3 players while Marionette Kingdom is for 2 to 3 players.

One player distributes cards in a similar vain as in One Night Werewolf. The other players can only look at their cards, but can exchange their card with an (unknown) card from another player or a card that has been set aside.

Then cards are resolved, giving victory points or allowing to build buildings.

Name: TimeWinder
Description:
A card game of time and space, where quantum mechanics decides the cards you are dealt, but you decide the outcome. You now have the chance to craft powerful machines, use wondrous items and collect valuable treasures and artifacts.

The game can be enjoyed by both newcomers and veterans, and although it can be easy to learn, it can be tricky to master. Amassing the most points by the end of the game determines the winner. Timing and the choices you make can be the difference between a winning and losing strategy. Every turn is a chance to snatch victory from your opponents.

The game is themed in a steampunk setting with elements of futuristic to implausible designs. A quick-paced tactical card game for 2-6 players.

—description from the designer

Name: Dark War: Roleplaying in a World Gone Mad
Description:
A Simple Game
Dark War uses a simple system, based on a single rule. Anytime you role a 4 or greater you get a success. That success might mean you pump two AK-47 rounds into a werewolf, or that your nurse heals a team member, or a witch gains control of a weak-minded soldier, forcing him to fire on his comrade. What varies are the dice that you use. When building your own character, you assign a fixed number of dice (4 x D4, 3 x D6, 2 x D8) to seven attributes--Shooting, Melee, Speed, Intelligence, Charm, Will, and Dodge-- to determine what type of individual you control. The more dice and the better the dice assigned to an attribute, the greater chance you have or rolling successes. But the customization doesn't end there. You can use experience points to buy Kickers, such as "Rifles," which adds an extra D6 when firing a rifle or "Power of Prayer" that allows a character to heal a teammate within two squares. Two many options? Just choose a group of pre-generated characters from the bestiary, slap them on the provided map, and have at it. Or, if you prefer, you can fight out one of the three, included skirmishes

Obviously attributes such as Charm and Intelligence can be put to great use when roleplaying, but Dark War's unique Action Cards ensure they are relevant even when fighting a quick skirmish.  For example, when an opponent activates a character you can slap the Fear Action Card on them, forcing them to pass an Intelligence test or lose all their actions. Other Action Cards can reload a weapon, add a die to melee, or even heal a wound.

When the fighting breaks out, characters determine initiative by rolling a combination of their Speed and Intelligence dice. The total determines when they act (higher is better, obviously) the number of successes determines how many Actions they have. Simple, fluid, and highly interactive.

Many RPGs say "Here are the rules, now go buy your own stuff to play with." Dark War is different. In each game you get the core rule book, 18 Action Cards, a 17" x 22" battle map depicting a West German village, and 70 1" square counters that include Russian and American soldiers, civilians, werewolves, vampires, witches, dead folks, zombies, and more. Better still we include a handful of stands, enabling the counters to functions as standees. It's like having your own set of Dark War minis. Furthermore, the rules include three ready-to-play skirmish scenarios (In the Beginning, Stranger Things, My Enemies' Friend) and a beginning-level, one to two session adventure titled, The Escape, complete with generated characters.  When we say "Ready to play," we mean it.

It's a small unit skirmish game, it's a roleplaying game, it's straight-up fighting or weird war combat. It's whatever you make it. It's the Dark War Roleplaying game.

Frequently Asked Questions
Can I play the skirmish game solitaire? Sure, you just have to play each side to the best of your ability.
Can I use my own miniatures? Of course you can. You can use your own minis, terrain you have made, 1" square battle maps that you have bought, or even hex maps. Nothing in the game precludes that. The difference in Dark War and many RPGs is that you aren't REQUIRED to buy that. We give you everything that you need.

Name: Ashes Reborn: The Ghost Guardian
Description: Death has given Rimea Careworn sight beyond sight. Her eyes now burn forever with visions of the Spirit World, where the souls of the dead test the boundaries of eternity, hungering to be free. Rimea has returned to the world of the living, and she now leads an army of lost souls to reclaim the city of Shadowreck. She will not stop until those responsible pay for their crimes, for only then will her ancestors’ spirits be at peace. Unleash powerful Illusion and Sympathy magic to raise ancient warriors from beyond and cast out the enemies of the Spirit World.
Families: Game: Ashes – Rise of the Phoenixborn

Name: Ashes Reborn: The King of Titans
Description: In Aenda Woodrass, the denizens of the desert oasis have struck a delicate accord with the laws of Nature. Xander Heartsblood rises to defend that accord to the death. Calling upon the ancient ways of the nomadic shamans as well as the terrifying power of his dinosaur conjurations, Xander channels the raw magic of Nature to bear down on those who would invade the sacred ground he now calls home. Balance the power of Nature and Divine magic to unleash the titans of the desert on unsuspecting prey.
Families: Game: Ashes – Rise of the Phoenixborn

Name: RONE (Second Edition)
Description:
RONE — Races of New Era — is a strategic post-apocalyptic card game for 2 or 4 players. Players are immersed in a dark world full of destruction and suffering, a world where people are fighting to take back their place after a global nuclear war annihilated all achievements of the human race and all that was left was only a handful of usable resources.

This second edition of RONE includes the core game, plus the New Forces and Awakening expansions in one box. There is new content as well, including features, new art, and add-ons. For back compatibility with the first edition, the cards are populated with an expansion symbol to easily distinguish which card belongs to which expansion.

Name: Jönköping: Spelet om din stad
Description:
Jönköping - Spelet om din stad ("Jönköping - The Local Game") is yet another of those Monopoly-style games that Swedish Local Authorities love to commission from games publishers.

In this case it was Gothenburg-based games publisher We Are Sailing (now defunct) that created the game.

The game is about the modern Municipality of Jönköping (Jönköpings kommun), which explain why the towns of Gränna and Huskvarna is present in the game (included in the Municipality since 1971). Historically, geographically and culturally Jönköping (founded 1284), Gränna (founded circa 1690) and Huskvarna (founded 1911) is quite separate entities. Also, the isle of Visingsö (a former countryside council in its own right) features fairly prominently in the game.

The game is estimated to have been published in 2008.

Name: War Thunder: Siege
Description:
War Thunder: The Siege is the classical cooperative Castle Panic game in the setting of World War II. Destroy the enemy troops in cooperations with your friends. There are no winners and losers. You will win or die together.

German troops are going to siege this strategically important city. The Wehrmacht is storming the fortifications the Red Army and the allies, and only you have the strength to keep the line. Can you destroy the enemy or you will allow him to wipe the city?  Fight together with your allies and share the win or defeat!

Name: Oceania
Description:
Oceania is a family game about shipping and (actually) maintenance of ships. Palet spil co-operated with marine paint manufacturer Hempel's Marine Paint in making this game and the Hempel's features repeatedly on the game board - the name of the ship that appears on the box front is Hempaturi after the "Hempatur" brand of paint, for example.

The mechanism is movement through a single track using the two kinds of cards in the game - "steering wheel" or "anchor", with some event spaces added. Winner is the first to reach the destination.

An artist signature "Bergholm" can be seen at the box lid picture, but not on the game board, while the Finnish edition is signed "Engholm".

The publishing year is estimated at circa 1980 given Palet ceased operations in the 1980's.

Name: Greetings Fellow Humans!
Description:
A game of extra-terrestrial antagonism for 3–5 players!

You are an alien! Your objective is to steal the Earth’s defense codes and conquer the planet.

In this fast paced party game, you must collect Intel cards from  several search piles each with its own risks and rewards, the higher the risk the more likely you will gain the precious Intel but, try to avoid the Accident cards as they call attention to you and your plans.

Each player has access to a variety of Gadget and Sabotage cards to help them, or to hinder other players.

Collect the Intel, escape the secret compound and win the game, before you are discovered!

–description from the designer

Name: Bull Shit
Description:
Bull Shit is an incredibly exciting party game for 2 to 6 players.

Be the first to get rid of your seven cards by performing the commands dictated by the surprising 8-sided dice. Challenge your friends, match your bluffing skills to perfect timing and a healthy dose of luck, and who knows, you could be the new bullshitt(ing) champion!

—description from the publisher

Name: Canal du Midi
Description:
The game takes place in 1667, after an edict signed by Louis XIV launched the construction of a canal to connect the Atlantic Ocean to the Mediterranean Sea. Pierre-Paul Riquet is tasked with coordinating this gigantic building project but he needs your help.

In the shoes of one of his engineers, you mission is to build as many sections of the Canal as you can, using available resources the best way possible. Players compete to measure the manpower necessary for each section and earn recognition from Pierre-Paul Riquet. But sudden reinforcements could change the game!

When the Canal du Midi is finished, the player with the most recognition points for the sections they helped build has won the game.

—description from the back of the box

Canal du Midi is a quick game played over 9 rounds in about 15 minutes. Players have 9 worker cards, representing varying amounts of manpower. Three of these cards are taken up into their hand, three are open on the table in front of them, and the remaining three form their draw deck. They also get 2 coins.

Each turn, a single section of the canal is revealed that is to be build this turn, and players bid a secret amount of manpower to help complete the section by playing one of the cards from their hand. If the total amount of manpower is enough to complete the section (i.e. beats the target set by the card), the player(s) who bid the most receive recognition points. However, before the section is awarded, all players get the opportunity to spend one of their coins to call up reinforcements. After players have decided whether or not to do so, each player spending a coin may draw a random card from the discard pile, and add the manpower on the card to their bid.

At the end of a turn, players draw a new card to bring their hand size back to 3 (if possible). They can draw either the top card of their drawing deck (blind), or one of the 3 open cards (which will get replaced by the top card of the deck). Play continues until all 9 sections have been built (or at least started, if the manpower fell short), and players have played all of their cards. Whoever has the most recognition points is the winner.

Name: Project Mars: Moving Forward
Description:
Project Mars—Moving Forward is the first expansion for Project Mars. It consists of 27 cards—15 are email (Events) and 12 are New Employees. A phase is added between the existing Pay Day and Place Module phases.

Also included are the Player Board Overlay cards. Place these on player boards when playing with this expansion to reflect the changes in turn phases.

The new email cards change things up by adding more player interaction and some unpredictable events, and now there's even more incentive to acquire a Test Flight card as it can protect you from Space Debris. The New Employees cards give you some powerful abilities and keep things Moving Forward.

-description from designer

Name: Canimals: We Can Do It
Description:
The stars of the Korean children's television show Canimals are the pieces in a curling/shuffleboard style flicking dexterity game.

Two players select four pieces each from the following characters: Nia, Pow, Oz, Uly, Fizzy, Mimi, Ato, and Leon.  In alternating turns, each player flicks one of their pieces towards the target at the end of the mat.  Players score points depending on how close each of their character pieces are to the center of the target.  After ten rounds, the player with the most points wins!

Name: Towerblox
Description:
Towerblox is an early implementation of the block-stacking game that would be popularised by Jenga, but predating the release of that title by a year, and with 39 blocks to Jenga's 54. The packaging is in English and German, unusual for the early 1980s.

Gameplay is much like Jenga except the blocks are stacked on their sides, leaving space between them.

Published by Games Workshop, it was not a success on release. According to Ian Livingstone the rights to the game were sold to the creators of Kensington.

—user summary

Name: Lobsterman's Lot
Description:
From the manual:
"Find out for yourself what lobstering's all about. You never know what's in store for you. It may be verry bountiful, or full of perils - just like the Lobster Industry. Lobsterman's Lot is a fun game. Fair weather or foul, you're in for a treat, so 'come aboard and haul on your dory!' See what a lobsterman's lot in life is like."

In this game, the players move their fishing boats around the board purchasing bait, catching lobsters and crabs and selling them for money. The goal of the game is to be the first player to reach $7,000.

Name: Empyreal: As Above, So Below
Description: This expansion for Empyreal: Spells & Steam adds a solo mode through an automata deck and support for two more players, plus 11 more specialist tiles and 24 more spellcar tiles.

Name: Nya Geni
Description: Nya Geni is a trivia game that is played much like Trivial Pursuit: you walk around the circle of questions and when you've got an correct answer in all six categories (actually marked with a small colored chip laying at the table, nest to the player - no pie slices here!), you move into the central area and answer a final question chosen by the opponents. First to do so wins.

Name: Föräldrafritt
Description:
Föräldrafritt ("No Parents") is a fairly simple childrens game for the age group 8 to 14.

Spin the spinner and move on the board, draw an apropriate card and do what is says. It could be singing, acting or guessing - and it is all about yourself, your mates, the school, the life as a young teen. The outcome of your task will affect gameplay. Eventually one player will reach the last square - and win!

While being a board game the aim is probably more to have fun and laughter (and perhaps a few embarrasing moments) than actually to make grand strategic plans etcetera.

Name: Eastern Mystery
Description:
Many hundred years ago, in the country across the sea and mountains lived an ancient eastern nation. They were ruled by cordial and gracious Emperor who was the main reason of their stable and peaceful existence. To proceed the Emperor’s graceful time people believed in him and served him. On the other hand, the Emperor had many foxy enemies. One day, the emperor received an invitation to the marriage ceremony. Betrayers immediately took advantage of the situation, attacked the emperor with poisonous liquids and killed him. The Emperor has gone. Your day is now to make your mark on Eastern History! A man leaves behind marks that associate his name with symbol of either admiration or hatred.

Number of players: The design of this mystic game based on Eastern History where 1-6 players act as heir to the throne. Those that were not frightened showed courage and determination and reshape the history of the East.

Time required: A single game takes approximately 15-20 minutes per player. Eastern Mystery is a well-ordered, complex and smooth game. In other words, the game is intuitive and simple enough for new gamers to be able to jump right in with plenty of tasks to complete. Additionally. By giving in the player becomes an underdog, and hunts down his fellow players.
The board shows an ancient carpet with original eastern features and players take turns rolling dice on 18x6 grid to conquer six different thrones.
Six different Characters, particularly different Tiles and their relationships define the game as a rule-based system specifying what there is, how the player can interact with them. Points are awarded for collecting sets of thrones, and in the end of final set the player with the most points becomes the winner. 
Eastern Mystery uses simple rules, but involves various tasks such as “Open Sesame” “Flying carpet”, “Doors” and “Jinnee” our famous figure: which is very curious about all and interested in your curiosity as well! The more you play the more nuances you will discover. The player who gains the maximum number of thrones in the end will be crowned as the winner! 
Prove your worth in an intense duel against an intricate game.

—description from the designer

Name: Geomemorix
Description:
An abstract game of memory and observation.

Contents: 8 round cards, 42 rectangular cards.

Preparing to play: Lay the 8 round cards out face down in 2 rows in between the players. Place the rectangular cards face down in a pile next to the round cards.

To win cards, you have to memorize the location of shapes and colors.

On your turn, turn up the top card from the draw pile, and place it next to the stack:

• If this card features two colored symbols, then you must find at least one of these two symbols (same color, same shape) on one of the round cards, and to do so you turn over a single card.

• If you turn up a card showing 1, 2 or 3 white symbols: you must then turn up 1, 2 or 3 round cards all featuring that symbol, regardless of color.

If you turn up the correct card(s), you win the rectangular card and play again.

Otherwise leave the card on the discard pile and it is the next player’s turn.

Turn the round cards back face down in the same place.

The next player can decide to try to win the card face up on top of the discard pile (if there is one) or to turn up a new rectangular card.

Only turn the round cards up to see if they feature the symbols you are looking for, and always turn them back face down at once.

All players take advantage of each round of the game to try to memorize the symbols on the round cards.

The game ends when there are no cards left in the draw pile. The player who has won the most cards wins the game.

Name: Rack Patrol
Description:
Rack Patrol is a solitaire, tactical-level, card-driven submarine war game. You take on the the command role of a single Gato-class submarine during WWII, on the hunt for Japanese targets in the Pacific.

The game is entirely card-driven. The operation cards are held in your hand or set on the table as a draw deck. You will be instructed frequently to draw a card from the operation deck in order to determine the outcome of a given action or to gain other information. You earn victory points at the end of a patrol based on the ships you have sunk during that patrol.

A single patrol (round) only takes about 10 minutes to play. However, due to the round/patrol-based structure, and because every patrol is an independent session of play, you can easily play longer, campaign-style games across multiple sittings. The game can be entirely packed up and put away between patrols. Simply record your running score at the end of any patrol and resume the game later.

There are many great submarine games out there already; what makes Rack Patrol unique is its size and portability. The entire game is played with a single deck of cards and one small player board. It takes up extremely little surface space. In fact, you could play the whole game while laying in your rack, whether that means you're aboard a submarine, or your sleeping partner already rolled over and knocked out, and you still want to get some gaming in.

-description from designer

Name: Buffalo Bill's Wild West Show in 6 Acts
Description:
Buffalo Bill's Wild West Show in 6 Acts was published by American Tobacco Company, with paper pieces distributed inside cigarette packs.

The game consists of thirty-eight separate pieces, a game board (referred to in the rules as a "base"), and a "program", including instructions.  The various paper pieces can be arranged (according to the program) to provide various scenarios (the "6 Acts") for play.  Scenarios could be played only once the player had accumulated the required pieces from purchased packets of cigarettes.

The six scenarios include: Act 1 - Attack on Deadwood Coach; Act 2 - The Rescue; Act 3 - Buffalo Riders, Bucking Bronchos, Etc.; Act 4 - Surrounding a Wagon Train; Act 5 - Scalp Dance; and Act 6 - The Last Stand.

An annotated copy of the game is on display at the Buffalo Bill Center of the West in Cody, Wyoming.  In the museum, the actual game pieces have served also as inspiration for life-size steel cutout "pieces" that are used throughout the display area to present various aspects of Buffalo Bill's life and times.

–user summary

Name: Fate/Grand Order Duel
Description:
F/GO Duel is a Miniature Board Game revolving around Mini Figures and Command Card. Similar to another official F/GO Tabletop game "Fate/Grand Order Summon Pencil Servant", this game also heavily involves "gacha elements" (Heroic Spirit Summoning). Battles using these mini figures will take place on top of a board (battlefield) and players will use Command Card to execute certain attacks

Source: Fate/Grand Order wikia

Name: Sten, Saks & Papir
Description:
Board game inspired by rock-paper-scissors. Each player has six pieces each showing a hand gesture (two of each of rock, paper and scissors).
The game is chess-like and you get points for taking the other player's pieces.

Name: The Whole Sad Story: The Battle for West Timor, February 20-22, 1942
Description:
The Japanese attack on the Island of West Timor, in the Dutch East Indies, was anticipated by the Allies as early as late December 1941. Soon after the start of the war, Sparrow Force, comprised mostly of Australian troops as well as some from the Dutch East Indies and Great Britain, occupied West Timor and began preparing defensive works.  This would allow a defensive island fortress between the expanding Japanese Empire and Australia.

To assault and secure the island, especially the airfield at Penful, the Japanese planned an amphibious assault supported by an ambitious paratrooper air-assault by the 1st and 3rd SNLF (Special Naval Landing Force) Battalions. The resulting fight for West Timor resulted in a confused and bitterly fought battle that ultimately resulted in the destruction and capture of the majority of Sparrow Force, one of the largest and most tragic defeats in Australia’s military history. The Japanese paratrooper force was also savaged in the fighting, with nearly half of their number killed, seriously wounded, or missing. Those surviving paratroopers were dispersed throughout the Pacific in different commands and never performed another combat jump in the war.

Can you do as well or better than your historical counterparts? Learn and enjoy!

-description from designer

Name: Carthago: Merchants & Guilds – Golden Achievements
Description: The Golden Achievement Tiles offer additional ways for players to earn points at the end of the game or, in exchange for the potential to earn extra points, players can take an additional turn during the game.

Name: Refugee Journeys
Description:
Refugees are human beings. The journey doesn’t end with arrival in a new country. This educational tool explores themes of belonging, identity, discrimination and culture in a hands-on experiential way.

Refugee Journeys is based on a simple "snakes and ladders" game concept - players move forward, backward, or miss turns based on the cards they draw or the spaces they land on. Cards include integration experiences of real refugees, drawn from academic research, news and media, and the game creator's personal experiences. Examples are: "You are 65 years old. You want to learn English, but the topic is always about finding a job. Move back a space." "You were sponsored to a rural area, where there is no bus transportation. You always have to ask for rides. Move back two spaces." "Your child has made a friend at school. Move forward a space." Players move through the game using an "Identity card" which details their country of origin, family background, housing situation, gender, and many other identity markers. As they move through the game, their identity influences the path they take. For example, one space on the board says, "Are you Muslim? Move back 2 spaces." The game critically highlights experiences of discrimination and profiling.

While the goal of Refugee Journeys is for players to move from the "start" to the "finish," the real purpose of the game is to establish a space for critical conversations about refugee experiences, integration, and the intersectionality of identity. To this end, after every experience card is played, players choose a discussion question from options printed on the board to talk about as a group. The discussion questions cover topics related to identity, injustice, policy, and allow for players to share their personal experiences with the topic.

Name: War Blog
Description:
Warblog offers over 500 print and play modern war hex and counter games.

The game covers 1945 to date period with current wars covered.

Many of the games offer exceptional replay-ability, whilst some are simply to analysis and learning.

With over 500 games, there are games to suit most timeframes. You can find small games that might only take 30 minutes to play, but you can play it multiple times, playing for the best of three or best of five. Other games could be described as monster games that will literally take a very long time.

A key feature of the system is its simplicity. They games are designed for people that have a penchant for moving the counters about and not having to wade through large rule sets. Further, as the games are mostly situational, ie not operational, lines of supply and command are not critical, although some games do offer leader units and there are leader rules. The game has been designed to be failsafe from the ground up. This means you just move the counters about, observing movement allowances and terrain etc, but if you don't understand surround rules or terrain defence effects, its not that important, just play anyway. But if you want to tighten things up, there is a deep set of mechanics, including unit mix/matching, that is gaining a bonus for armour versus infantry stacks with no armour or mechanised etc.

The game includes all unit types including air and sea units with a wide range of additional units types for air defence, insurgents and irregular activity.

The scenarios are all historic and players are encouraged to learn their history and to even criticise the orders of battle and terrain arrangements as doing so is only further developing your own historical understanding and helping the War Blog team to help other people similarly.

The scenarios also encompass current events, so if you have an interest in following world events you can use War Blog to do so.

Many of the scenarios included are largely unstudied and certainly not common knowledge, and this whole library of scenarios is always on the increase with scenarios being updated with new intelligence and new scenarios added.

The game is currently under development and the rule set could well branch out to encompass features not covered on the online version which can readily be added to a paper based procedural rule set, for example, hidden movement and political intervention. Further, experienced players are encouraged to add their own rules up.

Many of the scenarios are unbalanced and there mainly for situational analysis, for example, in a educational environment. However, even in situations where a player might not stand a chance of winning, players can set house scoring based on how long a player could hold out and how they play in comparison to the historical timeline.

—description from the designer

Name: Human Interface: Nakamura Tower – Officer Guttierez
Description:
Raid 44 Police Team Officer.

Box content:
1 metal miniatures
1 ID cards
2 weapon and gear cards
1 plastic bases

Name: Miner 49r
Description:
Miner 49r - Dice Game is a grid movement/dice placement game where you are a miner searching for GOLD, GEMS, JADE and DIAMONDS. You start at level 1 and as you search each level you progress down to the next level of the cavern. You will be digging within a hex grid using directional movement dice. You have TNT that you can use to blow up granite sections that block your path. Each level has an entrance to the next lower depth and as you dig your way through the cavern you must decide whether you can grab the precious minerals and make it to the exit or just get to the exit before you get stuck!

—description from the designer

Name: Smoke eleQtro plus
Description:
Smoke eleQtro plus is a game based on cigarettes.

Players compete for how many cigarettes they can smoke before dying from blackened lungs from both mainstream smoke and secondhand smoke.

"Mainstream smoke" is smoke directly entering the lungs. The lungs of smokers are black. On the other hand, "secondhand smoke" is the smoke emitted by smokers that affects people in the area. It is also called "passive smoking".

Basic Flow of Game 
Each player puts up to two cards from a hand of three to the table.

Only those with the largest number of cigarettes on the card will succeed in smoking.

At that time, the lung will become black as many as the number of lung markers on smoking cigarettes. If there is a secondhand smoke on that card, other players who fail to smoke will also receive a lung marker. Even though they were not able to smoke, the lungs slowly become black and bring everyone closer to death.

When only one person is still alive, the game ends and the player who smoked the most cigarettes will win.

Name: Tiny Trees
Description:
Tiny Trees is a competitive tree-building board game designed for 2-4 players, where you play as a minor nature spirit trying to become the next Demigod of Trees! Unlike a lot of board games that lie flat on your table, the trees you grow branch out of your table and into the third dimension.

The way the game works is that you start with a trunk and some roots, and you take turns slotting together hexagonal cards, called branchlets, so that by the end of the game, you’ll have something that looks like an actual tree!

Then, depending on how you grew your tree, you earn favor, or points, for a variety of factors, with the spirit who earns most wins and becomes the next demigod of trees! From the moment you open up the box, you’ll be creating something you can be proud of. So now go out and grow some trees.

—description from the designer

Name: Salvat Trivial Rock
Description:
The Salvat Trivial Rock is a game based on questions and answers around the world of rock. It is played with a board on which some pieces move, similar to chess pawns, which we will call "receivers"; On each receiver, one per player, other pieces that we will call "gold discs" are inserted.

Players will move their receivers across the board using a die and as they respond correctly to the questions on the cards.

The first objective is to conquer six gold discs. Once this goal is achieved, the assault on the final objective can be attempted: the conquest of a "platinum disc".

The player who wins the "platinum disc" wins the game.

Name: Curse of the Shadow Spire
Description:
A shadowy spire has arisen nearby and with it came evil shadow creatures that have been ravaging the countryside. As a great champion of the kingdom, your challenge is to travel the lands gathering weapons and allies with the goal of assaulting the spire and ridding the land of shadows forever.

Curse of the Shadow Spire is a solo game that can be played in about 30 minutes. 

You will play as one of four heroes of the realm. Each hero has different goals and route to victory. They will need to explore and locate three powerful relics to gain access to the shadow spire.

Each turn you will adventure and explore a new terrain hex. There you will uncover the mysteries of the realms. Visit locations such as Temples, Markets, and Catacombs. Endure events such as Traps, Curses, and Plages. Fight evil Shadows. And slay the Shadow Dragon to gain one of the three relics you will need to gain access to the Shadow Spire.

As the game progresses the Shadow Spire will gain strength. Once you have found all three relics and gained access to the spire you may assault it in an attempt to defeat the shadow forces guarding it and win the game.

You will play as one of four heroes: 

Crusader: As the Crusader you will be recruiting an army of Knights to help you defeat the shadows of the spire. You will need to defeat shadows, and venture into dangerous catacombs to gain the precious gold that you need to buy Food for your troops and recruit additional Knights.

Wizard: you will be working with dwarven miners to gather the finest arcane crystals buried deep in the mountains.  These crystals power you spells but you will also need to kill shadows and venture into dangerous catacombs to gain gold that you need to to hire them.

Ranger: you will be summoning powerful beasts and scouring the forest and crafting the most perfect arrows to aid you on your quest to defeat the shadows of the spire. You will need to kill shadows and venture into dangerous catacombs to gain gold that you can use to recruit powerful allies and heal your wounds.

Priest: you will be destroying shadows and gathering their essence to use against them in your attempt to defeat the shadows of the spire. You will need to kill shadows and venture into dangerous catacombs to gain gold that you can use to recruit powerful allies and tithe for blessings.

Multiplayer

As each hero plays differently, the game may be played by up to four players simultaneously. All heroes will work together to recover the relics but only the hero that defeats the spire will be honored as the grand champion of the realms.

—description from the designer

Name: LilleStorm på besøg
Description:
LittleStorm is visiting the park, play ground, city and more. It's a game for 2.5-6 year olds.

Collect tiles and learn about locations and vocabulary. The first player to complete four tiles - finishing with LittleStorm - wins.

Name: What in the Wild
Description:
What in the Wild is a game system consisting of a deck of 120 cards and rules for 5 different games. Cards contain plant and animal species and the food, water, shelter, and space they need to survive. Much as with wildlife conservation in the real world, the games of What in the Wild focus on cooperation, collaboration, or side by side competition rather than head to head competition. Each game was designed with children and families in mind, and most have variants that let you ramp up the challenge as players get older and are looking for more strategic gameplay.

•    Match It! A memory game where you explore the different types of habitat elements and which species use them.
•    Connect It! A cooperative game of map building to construct a resilient ecosystem before time runs out.
•    Slap It! A fast paced race to assemble habitat for as many species as you can.
•    Group It! A push your luck set collection game.
•    Build It! A collaborative game of habitat creation.

What in the Wild was designed to complement the Michigan Department of Natural Resources Wildlife Division’s “Go Wild for Michigan’s Wildlife” curriculum for kindergarten through 5th grade. A core element of the curriculum is introducing students to common wildlife species they may encounter and increasing their understanding and appreciation of these animals. This forms the heart of What in the Wild, and its games put their primary focus on fun, engagement, interaction, humor, and challenge. In a classroom setting, it’s a tool for teachers to use to extend student understanding of course content. For a family, the emphasis is on providing fun games that the youngest and oldest members can enjoy together.

description from designer

Name: Petrichor: Honeybee
Description:
The second expansion to Petrichor deepens the game: bringing a new action, a new resource (honey), four new tiles, and a giant bee to fly around!

Pollenate your apple trees, your blueberry bushes, or your watermelon, collect more honey than your opponents, and use the bee to sneak into tiles where nobody expected you to get to!

The Honeybee expansion is for 1-4 players (including full solo support), and if combined with the Flowers expansion it also supports 5 player mode.

Petrichor just got sweeter.

—description from the designer

Name: Robinson Crusoe: Adventures on the Cursed Island – Mystery Cards I
Description: This Robinson Crusoe mini-expansion includes twelve new Mystery Cards, such as Very Old Map, Gun, Rusty Machete, Maggots, Olive Lamp, Black Slime, Exploding Sack, Rat's Lair, UP!, Burrow, Monkey and Wild Dog.  These can be added alongside the base set of Mystery Cards.
Families: Game: Robinson Crusoe – Adventures on the Cursed Island

Name: Final Challenge
Description:
Final Challenge is a party game so packed with action it does not have to pose as a drinking game! However, if you decide to drink while playing it please record the conversations next morning, and send them to us (we want a portion of the laugh too)!

Our seemingly harmless and colourful cards may give you a false sense of security, but after the first card is drawn you will be sent into a hectic and hilarious whirlwind of challenges. Watch your friends speak in an invented language, convince the rest of the group they are Satan himself, while someone is crying heavily for no apparent reason! And all of that while you are trying to use the force on a piece of paper, with a straight face on.

After some playing time and a couple of successfully performed challenges you may get cocky, as anyone would, which is usually when other players will use one of their special abilities to put you back in your place! It is not uncommon to get yourself in a situation where you have to perform more than one challenge simultaneously. One second you are trying to be the funniest, the next you are trying not to die of laughter because one of the players decided it was a good idea to call their mom at 3 in the morning to tell her they were arrested!
In this game you are competing to outplay everyone in a creative way and be the funniest, bravest and most resourceful. Perform the challenges successfully, delegate unwanted challenges tactically, use the active and passive abilities to your advantage and be the first to gather one of the cards of each type and unlock the Final Challenge!

Players draw a card and reads the challenge out loud. They then choose to: Perform the challenge themself, Ask for a volunteer to perform the challenge or Attack another player.  If the challenge is performed successfully, the player keeps the card.

The player with the most challenge card at the end of the game wins.

—description from the publisher

Name: Glorantha: The Gods War – Cosmic Monsters
Description:
Cosmic Monsters spawn once the great compromise is triggered. Leviathan and Androgeus generate victory points for players in their areas but never attack. At the end of each turn though the leviathan will travel the map and start eating units. Androgeus runs around the map spawning units for different players. The Juggernaut rolls around the board pulling units with it.

Contents: 3 Huge Miniatures 
3 Cosmic Monster Loyalty cards 
3 Cosmic Monster Gift Cards

During the Kickstarter campaign this was Glorantha: The Gods War – Monsters, but during production it was split into 3 separate boxes due to size constraints: Glorantha: The Gods War â€“ Dragons, Glorantha: The Gods War â€“ Chaos Monsters, and Cosmic Monsters.

One Dragon is placed on the map at the start of the game. One Chaos Monster is placed on the map when the Chaos Rift Opens. One Cosmic Monster is placed on the map when the great compromise first triggers.

Name: Glorantha: The Gods War – Elder Races
Description:
Glorantha: The Gods War – Elder Races adds 31 figures to Glorantha: The Gods War, along with 12 control cards, 10 gift tiles, a Dragonewt evolution marker, and an Elven (Aldraya) marker.

The 12 elder races included are: Boggles, Dragonewts, Ducks, Dwarfs (The Mostali), Elves (The Aldryami), Giants, Luthans, Maidstone Archers, Scorpion Folk, Slarges (Reptile Folk), The Vadeli, and Waertagi (Dragon Ships).

Name: No Lo Testeamos Ni Un Poco: El Musical
Description:
This expansion is all about music. There are cards that prompt you to play a song on loop during the game, dance constantly with another player, do an instrumental sound each turn, meow and even lipsync battle!
—user summary

This is an expansion for We Didn't Playtest This at All.

It includes 42 cards that are gonna make you dance, sing, hum, whistle and meow.

—description from the publisher
Families: Game: We Didn't Playtest This At All

Name: Flowchart of Life
Description:
Flowchart of Life is the game where one or several players struggle for happiness and survival on their way through the social realistic flowchart.
Sometimes you have a choice, but very often you have to roll a die and hope for the best.
Sometimes your skills that you have acquired earlier will be useful, and sometimes other players can help you.
This game is very quick to learn so all the best of luck with your life, both in this game and for real.

Name: One Deck Dungeon: Caliana
Description:
The fairy Caliana is the 6th adventurer for One Deck dungeon. She can transform blue dice into yellow or pink dice. She can also heal wounds.

Edit: This is in the One Deck Dungeon: Forest of Shadows expansion

Name: Flip Ships: Enemy Ship Promo
Description:
During set up, add this card to the enemy deck. 
During the enemy advance phase, this ship moves one row towards the atmosphere. If it enters the atmosphere, it inflicts 4 points of damage to the player's city. On the other hand, if this ship is destroyed, players will not receive damage this turn.

Name: Evil Baby
Description:
A Russian Roulette style NSFW card game, last player alive wins against an indestructible Evil Baby...Don't Lose Your Head!

Players take turns drawing cards, if you draw an Evil Baby Card you lose if you don't have a counter card to send it to another player or defense card to defuse the attack.

Each player starts with a Defense Card for fast loadout, or a Defense Card, Counter Card, Skip Card & Attack Card each. The aim of the game is to build as many defense cards in your hand as possible to ensure your survival.

Players must take turns picking a card from the deck in clockwise order from
the dealer, the dealer is voted for by group decision or coin toss if just 2 players.

EVIL BABY CARDS

If you draw an Evil Baby Card, you are out if you
don't have a Defence or Counter Card to play.
The Evil Baby Card always goes back into the
deck and then the deck is shuffled.

DEFENSE CARDS

When you draw this card from the deck
keep it in your hand for when you need to use it. 
If you play a Defence Card, you must discard the
Defense Card after use.

COUNTER CARDS

When you draw this card from the deck
keep it in your hand for when you need to use it.
You can play a Counter Card instead of a
Defense Card if you have one in your hand when
you draw an Evil Baby Card. Choose any player
to send the Evil Baby Card to and they must face him
immediately.

SKIP CARDS

When you draw this card from the deck
keep it in your hand for when you need to use it.
You can use a skip card to miss your go, you must
discard the card upon use. You must present the skip
card before you pick up a card on your turn.

ATTACK CARDS

When you draw this card from the deck
keep it in your hand for when you want to use it. 
Present this card to another player to pick up an
extra card on their go, the card must be 
presented during their turn but before they have
picked up their card. Multiple attack cards can  be
used by multiple players at once.

Important: When drawing extra cards, cards must
be drawn 1 at a time and each turn completed before
drawing the additional cards.

JUMP SCARE CARDS

When you draw this card from the deck
you must discard one of your cards immediately. 
If you have any cards in your hand, you must discard
one of them as soon as you draw this card type.

GOO GOO VOODOO CARDS

When you draw this card from the deck
you can choose whether or not to use it.
These cards change the rules of play, if you
draw one of these, you can choose to use the
special abilty the card offers, then card is 
discarded.

DOUCHE BAG CARD

When you draw this card from the deck
you must discard all of your cards immediately. 
If you have any cards in your hand, you must discard
all of them as soon as you draw this card type.
There is only 1 card of this type in the game and
definitely the most annoying card you can run into.

Name: Tierisch versteckt
Description:
What kind of hustle and bustle is happening on the farm? In Tierisch versteckt, all of the animals are playing hide-and-seek and trying to find the best hiding place! There are lots of hiding places: in the haystack, on the apple tree, and even between the pigs in their stall. Will you manage to find all of the animal friends? Waldi, the farm dog will help you. The best seeker wins the game! A lively hide and seek game. In more detail:

1. The seeker turns around or covers his eyes with the hands.
2. All of the other players now hide their animal friends in the hiding places.  
3. The seeker now taps on two hiding places to indicate where she thinks the animal friends are hiding. 
4. Additionally he rolls the color die and place Waldi at the hiding place that matches in color. He can also look in this hiding place.
5. For each animal that the seeker find, he may take a star from the middle and place it in front of him.

The game ends when a player has collected five stars.

—description from the publisher

Name: Fairly Fast
Description:
All aboard, please! In the colorful train collecting game Ziemlich Zügig, you have to collect the most train cars and attach them to your own locomotive, but this is not as easy as it sounds. Some cars can be attached only once a certain number have been collected. In addition, the collected passengers and action tiles help you make the longest train in the game, which is how you win the game! In more detail:

1. Move your figure in a clockwise direction to the next side of the game board.
2. Select one tile from one of the three stacks.
3. If you have completed a train car tile set, attach this set to your locomotive tile.
Optional: Use action tiles.

The game ends when two stacks on one side of the game board are empty. The player with the longest train wins.

Name: Dixit: Anniversary
Description:
Dixit… a surprising, enchanting and evocative game to be enjoyed with friends and family alike. This multi-award winning party game returns with Dixit: 10th Anniversary, an 84 card expansion pack.

All the illustrators of previous expansions have been invited to join the adventure again. With evocations of tales and myths from all around the world, their combined art leads to an amazing result! Get caught up in the Dixit spell and experience a new and amazing journey taking you far beyond your imagination…

—description from publisher

Name: The Reckoners: Kickstarter Promo Pack
Description:
The Reckoners: Kickstarter Promo Pack includes 6 Epic Cards, 4 Equipment Cards, 1 Rules Card, and The Reckoners: Untold Epics story booklet. This Promo Pack comes included with all Kickstarter copies of the game, but will not be included in the retail version of the game.

Note: It is packaged inside of each Kickstarter copy of the game, but there will be stand-alone packages of the promos sold separately for those who don't purchase a Kickstarter copy.

Name: Dominoplay: Fractions and decimals
Description:
The series Dominoplay, created by Flavio Fogarolo, offers fun, didactic games which are variations on the classic game of dominoes, excellent for supporting learning and automatisms, especially but not only in calculations.

Dominoplay enables children to have instant control of the right matches: in fact, each element has a multi-coloured edge, a sort of colour barcode, which identifies the quantity represented, despite being presented under a different guise. If children try to pair up dominoes with different values they’ll realise immediately.
Thanks to the effective checking system, they can play fractions and decimals dominoes independently, even with the tables they don’t know perfectly, without needing the constant supervision of an adult.
Each game is divided into three levels of increasing difficulty and you can choose to play with only the dominoes belonging to the first level, only those from the second or the third level, those form the second and the third level together or the whole pack.
Dominoplay is a fun didactic tool and is ideal for encouraging inclusion: by carefully choosing the groups of dominoes all children can learn and have fun!

Dominoplay – Fractions and decimals provides exercises on fractions and decimals, using pictures as well.

Name: Dominoplay: The Regions of Italy
Description:
Created by Flavio Fogarolo, expert teacher of compensatory and didactic tools for pupils with special educational needs, Dominoplay innovates the classic domino game to sustain learning in the geography curriculum area in primary school.  This box, in particular, concentrates on the regions of Italy.

HOW IT WORKS
The box contains 72 cards, divided into 3 groups:
• first group of 24 cards: regions in northern Italy
• second group of 24 cards: regions in central Italy
• third group of 24 cards: regions of southern Italy and islands

In turn, the groups are divided into two levels of increasing difficulty:

– the cards in the first level represent the name of the region with the coat of arms and the map of Italy with the region coloured in red.
– the cards in the second level represent the map of the region (only the external outline) with the location and name of the capital city, a picture of something characteristic from that region, with indications of the subject and its location, and names of cities and characteristic places of the region represented in road map format.

Game play can be organized by choosing the tiles based on the players knowledge.  For example, if the players know northern Italy very well, central Italy a little but, and southern Italy/islands not at all, all 24 of the northern Italy tiles can be selected, only 8 from the first level of the central Italy group, and none from the southern Italy/islands group, for a total of 32 cards in all.

Name: Weltindor's Stones
Description:
Weltindor's Stones is a fairly simple game to win, despite it actually being lightly complex. The board is set up with nine platforms, each of which is split into a 3 by 3 grid. The platforms are all set out about 3 inches from each other, and connected by bridges, which are 1 tile long and create choke points. The corners are elevated about 1 inch off the ground, which gives an advantage to the player on them by giving them a higher chance to attack successfully. Each player is given a corner and the board to the left of the corner. The corner itself is named the lead board. On each of that player's platforms, there will be one stone, which can be moved by other players by having three individual units on the same tile as that stone. The overall point is to get 5 stones to your lead board.

A single turn consists of placing five units and moving them as a group or single unit 5 times. A move can also be spent attacking an adjacent square. Different units have different abilities, such as being able to attack from 2 tiles, or moving 2 tiles at once.

5 basic soldiers can come together to form a barracks, which essentially acts as a factory allowing extra units to be placed at the beginning of your turn. Barracks have to be hit 5 times to be destroyed. The leftover neutral platform in the middle acts as free land to establish barracks for anyone who can get there.

Action cards are abilities that cost mana (You get 1 mana at the beginning of your turn.), and can be played whenever they are needed, not specifically on your turn.

—description from the designer

Name: Hail Caesar: Age of Caesar
Description:
This campaign sourcebook focuses on the Battles that brought Julius Caesar to power as Rome's first emperor and the covers the military beginnings of Imperial Rome.

—user summary

Gaius Julius Caesar was surely the most famous Roman of all time – conqueror, statesman and founder of an empire that would shape the destiny of the world. What’s more, we know just how great a commander he was because he took the trouble to write and tell us so, recording his heroic exploits in all their gloriously impressive detail.
Join the mighty Caesar at the beginning of his glittering career of conquest and refight one of his most famous battles against those heinous enemies of civilisation, the dreaded Germans led by none other than that ambitious fiend Ariovistus of the Suebi.

March with Caesar’s legions into the land of implacable savages as our hero subjugates the barbarous Gauls and confronts that most dangerous of moustachioed monstrosities the treacherous chieftain of the Arverni tribe, Vercingetorix.
Cross the Rubicon and cast your own dice as Caesar pursues his rival Romans across continents in the Roman Civil War, facing his most deadly challenge yet in the form of famed conqueror of the East, Pompey the Great. Fight by Caesar’s side as he wages war for mastery of the Roman World upon battlefields soaked in Roman blood.
Regretfully we cannot tarry, as did Caesar, in the arms of Egypt’s beautiful Queen Cleopatra, but we can join him for the concluding battles of the Civil War in Africa, where we shall at last confront Caesar’s relentless opponents together with the armies of that inveterate enemy of Rome, King Juba of Numidia.
With this supplement for Hail Caesar we invite you to come, see and conquer for yourself in a series of new scenarios representing key battles in the career of Julius Caesar. We take a detailed look at the armies of Rome and her enemies, and we consider the lives of some of the greatest Roman commanders of them all, together with suitable rules to represent them on the tabletop.

—description from the publisher

Name: Expedition Zetta: Andromeda
Description: The Andromeda expansion for the game Expedition Zetta adds new planetary systems to visit when you use the Quick Zetta deck. This expansion can be used alone if you want to make journeys that visit stars in only the Andromeda Galaxy, or it can be mixed with the standard deck that comes with the game (that features stars from the Milky Way).

Name: Black Orchestra: Conspirator Pack #1
Description:
Conspirator Pack #1 includes all 3 conspirators from the 1st Edition's Classified Pack, but have been updated for the new edition. There is also a new 4th conspirator.

- above description from publisher

Includes:

Fabian Von Schlabrendorff - Wehrmacht - Adjutant to Colonel Tresckow
Hjalmar Schacht - Civilian - President Reichsbank
Hans Gisevius - Abwehr - Diplomat and Abwehr agent
  plus
Sophie Scholl - Civilian - Student activist

Name: Black Orchestra: Conspirator Pack #2
Description:
Conspirator Pack #2 includes 4 new conspirators for Black Orchestra.

- above description from publisher

Includes:
Hans von Dohnanyi - Abwehr - Lawyer and Abwehr agent
Rudolf Christoph von Gersdorff - Wehrmacht - Intelligence Liaison
Wessel Freytag von Loringhoven - Wehrmacht - Colonel High Command
Wolf-Heinrich Graf von Helldorff - Civilian - Chief of Police

Name: Dragon Ball Z: Over 9000
Description:
The greatest fighters in the Dragon Ball Z universe have assembled to see who is the mightiest of them all! Part bluffing game, part deduction, Dragon Ball Z: Over 9000 has players selecting an iconic hero or villain from Dragon Ball Z and competing against their friends to be the first to get their power level over 9000!

The goal of the game is to become the most powerful fighter in the DBZ Universe. You accomplish this by attacking other players and by using power-ups.

At the beginning of each round, players draw tokens from the center pile and place them down on their character's four slots. Players then challenge another player in a duel and in order to participate in a duel the player much have at least one facedown slotted token. Turns go around the table until no players may duel each other.

When a player reaches "Over 9000", the game is over and they win the game.

-description from publisher

Name: Dragon Ball Super: Heroic Battle
Description:
It’s a fight for the future in Dragon Ball Super: Heroic Battle! A flicking fighting game, Heroic Battle has you flicking Goku, Vegeta, Goku Black, or Zamasu into your opponents to deal damage and gain power. Power up and unleash special flick attacks that can send your enemies bouncing off of each other, or even into ‘destructible’ 3D terrain! Collect the 7 Dragon Balls to make a wish and change the way the game is played!

—description from the publisher

Name: Band Room Blitz
Description:
Band Room Blitz is a party game designed for the quick witted wordsmith or the walking encyclopedia of bands at your table. Players create a unique band name based off of two categories played by the Band Leader (Color, Animal, Death, Noun, and more). Players can add extra criteria instantly with Modify cards. These offer ways to force a specific genre or name format, tweak the categories in play, and more options for throwing off your opponents.

Players can win bonus points for declaring real bands that fit the cards in play, and harder still they can add a time limit to each round.  Whether you're a pop culture whiz kid or a creative comedian, Band Room Blitz is a blast for any casual game night.

Name: Transformers Trading Card Game: Autobots Starter Set
Description:
The Transformers Trading Card Game is a battling card game designed for two players. Players build a team of Transformers character cards and power them up with a customizable deck of battle cards. Transformers character cards are twice the size of standard playing cards; they can be flipped from bot mode to alt mode and back, and they feature premium printing treatment on one of their sides. The deck of battle cards features Action and Upgrade cards to enhance Transformers character cards.

The Autobots Starter Set contains cards for two players to begin gameplay, and it features Optimus Prime, Bumblebee, Ironhide, and Red Alert character cards.

Name: Transformers Trading Card Game: Convention Edition
Description:
The Transformers Trading Card Game is a battling card game designed for two players. Players build a team of Transformers character cards and power them up with a customizable deck of battle cards. Transformers character cards are twice the size of standard playing cards; they can be flipped from bot mode to alt mode and back, and they feature premium printing treatment on one of their sides. The deck of battle cards features Action and Upgrade cards to enhance Transformers character cards.

The Transformers Trading Card Game – Convention Edition serves as an introduction to the game before it's officially released, with these preview cards being distributed at conventions such as Comic-Con International 2018 and Gen Con 2018. This pack contains two Transformers character cards (Cliffjumper – Renegade Warrior and Slipstream – Strategic Seeker) and two battle cards (All-Out Attack and Tandem Targeting System) not available in the Autobots Starter Set or Booster Packs.

Name: Transformers Trading Card Game: Booster Pack
Description:
The Transformers Trading Card Game is a battling card game designed for two players. Players build a team of Transformers character cards and power them up with a customizable deck of battle cards. Transformers character cards are twice the size of standard playing cards; they can be flipped from bot mode to alt mode and back, and they feature premium printing treatment on one of their sides. The deck of battle cards features Action and Upgrade cards to enhance Transformers character cards.

Each Transformers TCG – Booster Pack contains 1 Transformers character card and 7 battle cards from a pool of 40 character cards and 81 battle cards. Players can use these cards to customize their character card teams and battle card decks.

Name: Gunfighter's Ball
Description:
Gunfighter's Ball is a fun, fast-paced tabletop miniatures game of the Old West. The rules tie into a full range of highly-detailed digitally-designed miniatures from Knuckleduster Miniatures, and fall of 2018 will see the release of four card decks, poker chips, and a hardcover rule book in support of the game. Kickstarter materials (cards, buildings, books, etc.) will start going out to backers late summer of 2018 and be available to the general public shortly afterward.

Players choose two actions for their character when their card is pulled from a poker deck (players typically control two characters and each character is activated on a different card). 
Moving, firing, and would location and severity are determined using dice. Health points are tracked using poker chips which are cashed in as hits are taken. There are mechanisms for reacting to opponent's actions, as well as rules for mounted movement and other iconic western things.

Characters can be given special abilities to enhance game play, and optional card decks (released fall 2018) facilitate dealing out special abilities and wounds rather than using charts from the book.

Right now, miniature figures, buildings and other terrain, custom dice, and a free set of rules are available from Knuckleduster.

—description from the publisher

Name: Triple Cross
Description:
Players engage in a head-to-head battle by placing discs in the innovative Triple Cross tower. Your aim is to have more vertical and diagonal "3-in-a-rows" than your opponent.

Game play is unique in that players push a disc into the row from the side. If the push in another disc, the first disc played is moved up along the track. If a 3rd disc is played in the same row, the disc in the middle is dropped down one row - and if a 4th disc is placed the first disc played is popped out the side.

There is subtle strategy in where to place the discs and when to use the blockers to lock a row.

—description from the publisher

Name: Ice Pop Swap
Description:
The object is to be the first player to collect 4 Ice Pop Sticks of one color. But be on the lookout for the Icky Sticks - they will not count towards your winning collection.

—description from the publisher

Name: Storm in the East: Operation Barbarossa
Description:
Storm in the East: Operation Barbarossa depicts the largest and most dramatic military campaign in recorded history: the German invasion of Soviet Russia. Germany and its allies had almost five million men deployed in three army groups along the 800 miles of the Soviet border. As dawn broke on 22 June 1941, the first Axis formations crossed into the Soviet Union and smashed through units charged with defending the border. Taken completely by surprise, many were captured or killed while asleep in their barracks.  As the dawn bled into a new day, the Luftwaffe bombed airfields in western Russia destroying much of the Soviet air force on the ground, and German bombers attacked cities from Riga in the north to Odessa in the south.
 The invasion had achieved a total strategic surprise. At first, Stalin and the Soviet High Command were in a state of denial.  It was many hours before they accepted the reality of the situation and started issuing orders allowing local commanders to re-group and mount counterattacks.  Their paralysis only added to the chaos and confusion of the Soviet units at the front. It looked as though Hitler’s confident prophesy to his generals was going to be realised: “You have only to kick in the door, and the whole rotten structure will come crashing down.” 
â€‹
But it didn’t. Four months later, the Soviets were still fighting tenaciously and the character of the war had changed. In sight of Moscow, the Axis blitzkrieg had run its course: a war of manoeuvre and mobility had become war of attrition; a bloody slog as autumnal rains heralded rasputitsa and roads became quagmires. The vision of a rapid victory envisaged by Hitler had vanished.  
  
The historical outcome of Operation Barbarossa was the consequence of fateful decisions and extraneous events which conspired to produce a campaign unsurpassed in drama or scale.
